conclusion: Determine the volume of the measured solid using the device shown in the figure.
Reasoning process is based on principles of gas displacement and pressure-volume relationships.
C is the chamber where the solid is placed.
B is the bulb with a known volume V_B.
D is the U-tube manometer used to measure pressure changes.
K is the valve to control airflow.
A is the tube connecting the chamber and bulb.
Close the valve K and ensure the chamber C is empty.
Allow air to flow into the bulb B and chamber C and measure the pressure P_0 using the manometer when the system is in equilibrium.
Record the initial pressure P_0 and note the total volume of the system V_total = V_B + V_C.
Place the irregularly shaped solid inside the chamber C.
Close the valve K again and allow air to flow into the bulb B and chamber C and measure the new pressure P using the manometer when the system is in equilibrium.
Note the new effective volume of the system V_effective = V_B + (V_C - V_solid).
The ideal gas law states P * V = constant.
Express the relationship between pressure and volume as P_0 * V_total = P * V_effective.
Substitute the volumes: P_0 * (V_B + V_C) = P * (V_B + V_C - V_solid).
Rearrange the equation to isolate V_solid: V_solid = V_C - (P_0 * (V_B + V_C) / P) + V_B.
Simplify the equation: V_solid = (P_0 * V_C / P) - V_C + (P_0 * V_B / P) - V_B.
Using the measured values of P_0, P, V_B, and V_C, calculate V_solid using the derived formula.
